title: The Bridge and the City, Berwick-on-Tweed
provenance_text:
Sir David Young Cameron (1865-1945); George A. Hearn (1835-1913), New York, NY, by 1908 until December 1913[1]; George A. Hearn estate, December 1913 until February 1918; sale, "The Notable Art Collection Formed by the Late George A. Hearn", American Art Galleries, Plaza Hotel, New York, NY, February 25-March 4, 1918, lot 166 [2]; M. Knoedler and Co., New York, NY and London, February 26, 1918 until November 24, 1925 [3]; purchased by Department of Fine Arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, PA, November 1925 [4].

Notes:
[1]. Included in "Catalogue of the Collection of Foreign and American Paintings Owned by Mr. George A. Hearn", New York, 1908, no. 77, illustrated on p. 62, as "Along the Clyde, Glasgow".  
[2]. This work sold on the second evening of the sale, February 26, 1918.
[3]. Listed as "The Bridge & the City", No.14355, in Knoedler New York stock books, February 1918, with a purchase price of $1500 and as "The Bridge and the City, Berwick-on-Tweed", No. 7477, in Knoedler's 1925 London stock book (see Knoedler Archive, The Getty Research Institute.)
[4]. The painting was shipped via Dicksee & Company from Knoedler, London to Pittsburgh for inclusion in the 1925 Carnegie International.  It was bought by the Carnegie Institute from this exhibition. The Knoedler New York sales book for November 1925 records the sale, as does a note in Knoedler's 1925 London stock book, which reads as follows: "sold by N.Y. to Carnegie Institute of Pittsburgh in November 1925".

creator.death_place: Perth (Perth and Kinross, Scotland, United Kingdom)
